str2: A primary particle; but, and, etc.
A primary preposition; 'fore', i.e. In front of, prior to.
All, the whole, every kind of. Including all the forms of declension; apparently a primary word; all, any, every, the whole.
This; he, she, it.

parse: Verb - Future Indicative Active - 3rd Person Plural
str2: From epi and ballo; to throw upon; specially to reflect; impersonally, to belong to.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Accusative 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Verb - Future Indicative Active - 3rd Person Plural
str2: To pursue, hence: I persecute. A prolonged form of a primary verb dio; to pursue; by implication, to persecute.
Or heneken hen'-ek-en or heineken hi'-nek-en; of uncertain affinity; on account of.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 1st Person Singular
str2: I, the first-person pronoun. A primary pronoun of the first person I.
Name, character, fame, reputation. From a presumed derivative of the base of ginosko; a 'name'.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Plural
str2: From para and didomi; to surrender, i.e yield up, intrust, transmit.
A primary preposition; to or into, of place, time, or purpose; also in adverbial phrases.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From sunago; an assemblage of persons; specially, a Jewish 'synagogue'; by analogy, a Christian church.
And, even, also, namely.
From phulasso; a guarding or, the act, the person; figuratively, the place, the condition, or, the time, literally or figuratively.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Middle or Passive - Accusative Masculine Plural
str2: To lead, carry, take away; met: To be led astray, seduced. From apo and ago; to take off.
On, to, against, on the basis of, at.
A king, ruler, but in some passages clearly to be translated: emperor. Probably from basis; a sovereign.
And, even, also, namely.
From hegeomai; a leader, i.e. Chief person of a province.
